title: CSS Links
subject: CSS
theory:
Links can be styled differently depending on what state they are in.

The four links states are:
*   `a:link`: a normal, unvisited link
*   `a:visited`: a link the user has visited
*   `a:hover`: a link when the user mouses over it
*   `a:active`: a link the moment it is clicked

ORDER MATTERS: Love Hate (LVHA) - Link, Visited, Hover, Active.

examples.output: A red rectangular button that acts as a link.
examples.explanation: Using padding and background color to transform a text link into a UI button.

common_mistakes.correction: Hover MUST come after Link and Visited. Active MUST come after Hover.

interview_questions.question: What happens if you define a:hover before a:link?
interview_questions.answer: The hover style may be overridden by the link style due to cascading rules if specificities are equal.

practice_problems.problem: Remove the underline from a link only when hovering.

real_world_use_cases.description: Links in navbars typically lose their underline and change color on hover to indicate interactivity.
real_world_use_cases.code: nav a:hover { color: #ff0000; border-bottom: 2px solid red; }

exam_notes: Default visited link color is purple.
summary: Properly styled links are crucial for navigation. Visual feedback on hover increases usability.
